clinical_study.brief_title: Parameters of Neurological Deficit After Thoracolumbar Fractures
clinical_study.official_title: Radiological Parameters Affecting Neurological Injury After Thoracolumbar Spinal Fractures

brief_summary.textblock: To detect Radiological parameters affecting neurological injury after thoracolumbar spinal fractures.

detailed_description.textblock:
Traumatic fractures of the thoracolumbar junction (T10-L2) are the most common spinal column fractures. High activity and lack of stability make it more prone to fractures.
Many studies have attempted to determine whether neurological deficit in such fractures is related to spinal canal stenosis or other parameters observed on axial computed tomography (CT). However, this relationship remains controversial.
Few reports shed light on the correlation between different imaging parameters like: sagittal alignment, vertebral compression, and canal stenosis, type of the fracture according to AO classification and severity of nerve damage.
These four radiographic parameters will be tested as expected risk factors for neurological deficit in thoracolumbar fractures .

primary_outcome.measure: neurological examination according to ASIA scale
primary_outcome.description: It is a scale that measures degrees of neurological deficit .

secondary_outcome.description: measurement by canal cross sectional area .
measurement by compression ratio of vertebral height.

study_pop.textblock: Any patient with Acute (within one month) thoracolumbar spine fracture above 18 years old with or without neurological deficit in orthopaedics and trauma department of Assiut university hospital from 1st of September 2017 to 31 st of August 2018.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Any patient with Acute (within one month) thoracolumbar spine fracture above 18 years old with or without neurological deficit
2. In orthopaedics and trauma department of Assiut university hospital from 1st of october 2017 to 30 st of september 2018.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients suffering from preoperative neurological diseases.
2. Patients with old thoracolumbar fractures.
3. Patients with pathological spine fractures.
